name: Iron
summary: Iron is an essential mineral required for hemoglobin production, oxygen transport, and numerous enzymatic processes. Supplementation is commonly used to treat or prevent iron-deficiency anemia.
description: Iron is a trace mineral vital for red blood cell formation, energy metabolism, and neurological function. It is found naturally in foods (heme iron from animal sources, non-heme iron from plant sources) and available as a dietary supplement. Iron deficiency can lead to anemia, fatigue, impaired cognitive function, and mood disturbances. Supplementation restores iron stores, supports cognitive performance, and improves energy levels. However, excess iron can be toxic and should be avoided unless deficiency is documented.

metadata.natural_source: Meat, poultry, seafood (heme iron); legumes, leafy greens, fortified foods (non-heme iron)
treatment_duration: Weeks to months depending on deficiency severity

primary_indications: Prevention of anemia in high-risk groups (e.g., pregnancy)
off_label_uses: Restless legs syndrome (when iron deficiency is present)
contraindications: Hemolytic anemia (not due to iron deficiency)

items: Restless legs syndrome with low ferritin levels

sections.text: Iron is required for hemoglobin and myoglobin synthesis, enabling oxygen transport and storage. It serves as a cofactor for enzymes involved in energy metabolism and neurotransmitter synthesis. Supplementation replenishes depleted iron stores, restoring oxygen-carrying capacity and reducing symptoms of anemia such as fatigue, weakness, and cognitive impairment.

adult.typical: 100–200 mg elemental iron daily in divided doses for iron-deficiency anemia
adult.note: Preventive doses during pregnancy: ~30 mg/day; treatment doses are higher.

sections.text: Reticulocyte response may be seen in 4–7 days; hemoglobin rises within 2–3 weeks. Full iron store replenishment often requires 3–6 months.

other: Accidental overdose in children can be fatal; store out of reach.
Excessive iron supplementation may cause oxidative stress and organ damage.
Take with vitamin C to enhance absorption; avoid taking with calcium, coffee, or tea.

sections.pregnancy: Commonly recommended for anemia prevention and treatment
sections.lactation: Safe; small amounts appear in breast milk
sections.pediatrics: Use age-appropriate formulations and dosing; risk of accidental overdose
sections.geriatrics: Monitor for constipation and absorption issues

sections.text: Continue supplementation for at least 3 months after hemoglobin normalizes to fully replenish iron stores; then taper or discontinue under monitoring.

items: Best absorbed on an empty stomach, but GI side effects may necessitate taking with food.
Liquid formulations may stain teeth; use a straw and rinse mouth.
